title: Boris Johnson finally wins a vote in the House of Commons
text:
This was his eighth time trying to win a key vote (Picture: Getty)

It’s a momentous day for Boris Johnson, as he has won his first vote in Parliament since becoming prime minister.

This was his eight time trying to win a key vote since taking office in July.

Conservative MPs cheered as they realised they were on course to pass regulations connected to Brexit.

‘I realise this is a unique moment but we must allow the result to be heard in full,’ said Deputy Speaker Dame Eleanor Laing.

It was then announced MPs had voted 280 to 204, majority 76, in favour of the Environment (Legislative Functions from Directives) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019.

The statutory instrument seeks to transfer post-Brexit a series of legislative functions from the EU to the UK connected to environmental policy areas, including air quality and marine and water quality.

Mr Johnson lacks a majority in the Commons which could explain why his last seven attempts to win votes failed.

The previous failed votes include:

MPs approving backbench legislation designed to stop the Government forcing through a no-deal Brexit on October 31

Two failed attempts to secure a snap general election as the Government fell short of the required two-thirds majority

Defeat on allowing a short recess for the Conservative Party conference.

Eighth time lucky (Picture: EPA)

Today might have been a minor victory, but the rest of this week will be a race against time to try and secure a Brexit deal in time for a crucial EU summit on Thursday and Friday.

The Guardian reported senior sources on both sides of the Channel saying that a draft treaty could be published on Wednesday morning after the UK agreed in principle there will be a customs border in the Irish Sea.

But the PM’s official spokesman said: ‘Talks remain constructive but there is more work still to do.’

Downing Street sources were also downplaying the chances of a breakthrough being imminent and an EU official stressed ‘talks are ongoing’.
